title: About
text:
This project was developed by Lean Mean Learning Machines For INFO 511 - Fundamentals of Data Science at the University of Arizona, taught by Dr. Greg Chism. The team is comprised of the following team members.

Team member 1: Tejas Bhawari - First Year Masters of Science in Data Science Student, RPA Developer
Team member 2: Michelle Le - First Year Masters of Science in Data Science student. Software Engineer for American Airlines.
Team member 3: Weiliang Deng - Second year phd student in systems and indistrial enginnering.
Team member 4: Vidhyananth Sivashanmugam - Second year - Master of Science Data science .
Team member 5: Diana Ayala - Second Year Masters of Information Science. Business Intelligence Analyst for Arizona State Univ

title: Proposal title
text:
import numpy as np
import seaborn as sns

title: Proposal title
text:
Introduction and data
For each data set:

Identify the source of the data.
State when and how it was originally collected (by the original data curator, not necessarily how you found the data).
Write a brief description of the observations.
Address ethical concerns about the data, if any.

Make sure to load the data and use inline code for some of this information.

title: Proposal title
text:
Research Question
Your research question should contain at least three variables, and should be a mix of categorical and quantitative variables. When writing a research question, please think about the following:

What is your target population?
Is the question original?
Can the question be answered?

For each data set, include the following:

A well formulated research question. (You may include more than one research question if you want to receive feedback on different ideas for your project. However, one per data set is required.)
Statement on why this question is important.
A description of the research topic along with a concise statement of your hypotheses on this topic.
Identify the types of variables in your research question. Categorical? Quantitative?

title: Proposal title
text:
Glimpse of data
For each data set:

Place the file containing your data in the data folder of the project repo.
Use the .head() and .info() functions to provide a glimpse of the data set.

title: Proposal title
text:
Analysis plan

A plan for answering each of the questions including the variables involved, variables to be created (if any), external data to be merged in (if any).

title: Proposal title
text:
import numpy as np
import seaborn as sns

title: Proposal title
text:
Introduction and data
Make sure to load the data and use inline code for some of this information.

title: Proposal title
text:
Research Question
This dataset, provided by Ankul Sharma on Kaggle (link), was last updated on October 15, 2024. It contains data on Netflix movies and TV shows with 12 columns: show_id, type, title, director, cast, country, date_added, release_year, rating, duration, listed_in, and description, while there are some missing values in the columns director, cast, and country.
The research question for this dataset is: “How do the country of origin, type of content (Movie or TV Show), and rating influence the release year of Netflix shows?” This original question aims to examine the relationships between these variables, focusing on the target population: all Netflix movies and TV shows available globally within the years included in the dataset. The analysis will involve the variables type, country, release_year, and rating, which include both categorical and quantitative data types.
This question is significant because understanding these relationships offers insights into Netflix’s evolving content strategy, regional preferences, and content type trends over time. Additionally, it provides a view into how Netflix ratings might be associated with certain types of content and regional production patterns, highlighting trends that could inform future content decisions.

Research Topic & Hypotheses
Research Topic:
Analyzing the characteristics and trends in Netflix content based on country, type, and rating across different years.
Hypotheses:
- H1: Netflix movies and TV shows from different countries show variation in their release years. - H2: The type of content (Movie vs. TV Show) has a significant influence on the rating it receives. - H3: Higher-rated content is more recent compared to lower-rated content. - H4: The length of Netflix movies and TV shows a positive relationship with its rating.
Variables: - Categorical Variables: Country, Type, Rating - Quantitative Variable: Release Year

title: Proposal title
text:
Glimpse of data
The dataset contains 12 columns, with the following relevant columns for our research question: - country: Country where the content was produced. - type: Whether the content is a Movie or TV Show. - rating: Content rating (e.g., PG-13, TV-MA). - release_year: Year when the content was released.

title: Proposal title
text:
Analysis plan

Data Exploration:
Use .head() and .info() functions for an initial exploration of the dataset to confirm data quality and presence of null values.
Variable Preprocessing:

Filter out missing values in the country and rating columns.
Convert release_year into a numeric format if necessary for consistency.

Statistical Analysis:

Perform comparative analysis by country and type to identify trends in release years.
Analyze rating distribution across different types and countries to detect patterns.

Hypothesis Testing:

Use appropriate statistical tests to validate the hypotheses above.

title: Project title
text:
Math Expressions
You can write LaTeX math expressions inside a pair of dollar signs, e.g. $\alpha+\beta$ renders \(\alpha + \beta\). You can use the display style with double dollar signs:
$$\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^nX_i$$
\[
\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^nX_i
\]
Limitations:

The source code of a LaTeX math expression must be in one line, unless it is inside a pair of double dollar signs, in which case the starting $$ must appear in the very beginning of a line, followed immediately by a non-space character, and the ending $$ must be at the end of a line, led by a non-space character;
There should not be spaces after the opening $ or before the closing $.

title: Car Recalls
text:
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import seaborn as sns

title: Car Recalls
text:
Introduction and data

car_recalls = pd.read_csv("./data/Recalls_Data.csv")


Identify the source of the data.
This data was collected by manufacturers who are required to report to National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) whenever they find a safety defect in their products. The safety guidelines of a product must align with the National Traffic and Motor Safety Act.
This dataset contains 15 columns, primarily consisting of categorical data such as manufacturer, components affected, recall type, etc. There are two numerical data variables - number of potentially affected products and completion rates, if available.

title: Car Recalls
text:
Research Question
Our target population can range anywhere from consumers of vehicles, vehicle components, or vehicle manufacturers themselves, as this data can be used to compare manufacturers, vehicles, and components with each other. This information can be useful for manufacturers to promote competition and production of better and more reliable products within this industry. It can also be useful to consumers so they can build more of an understanding for the most reliable vehicle and vehicle products that they can purchase from.
Potential research questions based on the data set:

Over the past 10 years, what is the trend of number of recalls? Overall? Over select manufacturers? Over component type?

For overall number of recalls, our hypothesis is that number of overall recalls have decreased
For select manufacturers, we can select a few manufacturers to hone in on (maybe based on other data indicating high/low number of vehicle sales), and compare number of recalls. Our hypothesis is that the proportion of sales to recalls are congruent between high/low number of vehicle sales over the past 10 years.
For component type, we can select certain components such as components specifically designed for passenger safety and hypothesize that recalls had decreased over the past 10 years
What’s involved: These research questions will involve quantitative data like number of recalls, number of potentially affected vehicles. It will also include categorical data such as manufacturers and component types. It will also deal with periodical data.

What products tend to be up for recalls?

Our hypothesis is that throughout the past 10 or more years, there have been more electrical recalls due to increase in hybrid vehicles.
What’s involved: This research question will deal with quantitative data such as number of recalls. It will also have categorical data such as recall types and component types.

Upon the recalls, what is the percent of completion rate?

Our hypothesis is that over the years, the completion rate overall has been increasing
What’s involved: This research question will deal with quantitative data such as completion rates, number of recalls. It will also deal with periodical data.

title: Car Recalls
text:
Analysis plan
Relative to the research questions stated above, here are the analysis plans for each of the questions:

1i) The variables involved would be number of recalls, number of vehicles potentially affected, and the dates of the report by year. We can make various analysis on this over a periodical graph indicating the trend of these numbers overtime.
1ii) The variables involved would be the number of recalls, number of vehicles potentially affected, the categorical data of component type, possibly the categorical data of recall type, and the dates of the report by year. We can also make a periodoical graph indicating trends overtime, and then group by and discuss about a select recall/component type.
1iii) The variables involved would be the number of recalls, number of vehicles potentially affected, the categorical manufacturer data, the categorical data of component type, possibly the categorical data of recall type, and the dates of the report by year. With this, we can make a periodical graph differentiating the trends over year by manufacturer and broken down further into component and recall type.
2i) The variables involved would be the number of recalls and the categorical data of recall type, component type, and the date of the report. We can test this hypothesis by comparing the number of recalls of electrical recalls over time
3i) The variables involved would be the completion rate, number of recalls, and the date of the report. We can test his hypothesis by mapping out trends in the completion rate over a period of time and seeing if there is a strong pattern amongst the trend.
